stream_context.summary: Kaze works on Course 13’s Raphael the Raven boss area, focusing on building the arena tower/nest set-piece and—more importantly—brainstorming the full boss fight structure (moon set-piece, anti-gravity/fall-into-stars interludes, and a damage mechanic). Mid-stream he also imports and manually sets loop points for the Ice Dungeon track, and shares broader project status (star/enemy counts, OST size) plus a few tooling/engine constraints that shape design choices.
stream_context.significance_reason: A complete high-level design for the Raphael the Raven boss fight is mapped out (phases, visuals, and damage loop), along with concrete next steps (moon/cutscene + planetary-gravity code). He also provides meaningful project-wide progress numbers (stars/enemies) and confirms the game’s unusually large OST count.

findings.summary: Kaze’s top priority for bosses is creating a memorable visual set-piece first, then fitting innovative gameplay to it; for Raphael the Raven, the moon/tower reveal is treated as non-negotiable spectacle.
findings.quote: It being a cool set-piece is my number one priority for bosses, always.

findings.summary: The stream’s main outcome is a sketched boss-fight loop: Raphael stomps/attacks to launch Mario into a ‘falling into stars’ dodge sequence; after landing on a (likely low-gravity) moon arena, Raphael performs a ground-pound that sends multiple projectiles around the moon that collide on the far side, spawning a throwable ‘unfrozen’ pickup used to damage him; repeat for multiple hits/phases.

Kaze explicitly rejects a true ‘hollow moon / inside-outside’ fight concept because it would require universal gravity changes; he wants the fight implementable mostly at the actor level to avoid risky engine-wide modifications.

Because the boss concept likely needs moon rotation/planetary-gravity-like behavior (even if simplified), Kaze plans to ask Arthur for existing planetary gravity code rather than reinventing it from scratch.
findings.quote: I’m going to ask Arthur for his planetary gravity code because he already knows what to do, I think.

findings.summary: He debates whether Raphael should be an ‘ice variant’ to match the ice ravens already used in the castle; however, the iconic intro visual (moon goes dark, eyes appear) pushes him back toward a darker/black Raphael for maximum ‘oh shit’ impact.

A specific thematic prop payoff is proposed: a nest in the arena containing an egg; after victory the egg ‘explodes’ into the reward star—framing the boss as guarding the egg. Kaze debates whether the egg should be a Raven egg or a captured Yoshi egg for story flavor.
findings.quote: There should be an egg here. And then at the end when you win, the egg just explodes and you get a star out of the egg.

findings.summary: He demonstrates hands-on audio implementation: imports an Ice Dungeon track and manually finds loop points by visually/aurally aligning beats, then converts loop timestamps into the game’s loop format (multiplying by 32) and tests in-game.

Kaze clarifies the project’s music pipeline: most of the OST is in an M64 ‘MIDI-like’ format using SAx64, with a smaller portion as streamed audio in a large custom format that must be used sparingly due to size constraints.

Project scope/status snapshot: ~98 songs are already in the build (he notes this exceeds Mario Odyssey’s track count), ~120 stars are done, overworld + enemies are in active development, and he estimates ~30% of enemies are implemented.
findings.quote: We are currently like 120 stars done and we're working on the overworld and the enemies.

findings.summary: He describes a Fast64 export bug: fog state can get ‘stuck on’ in a single large display list when using material bleeding, causing visual mismatches—he cites Course 12 looking more bugged on N64 than on stream due to this.

Kaze pushes back on a recurring audience desire for ‘more difficulty,’ arguing Mario 64’s core appeal is freedom and self-imposed risk; players can choose riskier movement lines for challenge without the game forcing it.
findings.quote: The point is that you're free. It's all freedom.

findings.summary: He avoids looking into the ‘gigaleak’ content, describing it as ‘cursed knowledge’ that could create trouble even from awareness alone.
findings.quote: Even just knowing about things in the gigaleak can get you in trouble. It's like the cursed knowledge.

biobak.summary: Kaze references a video concept Biobak sent earlier that he uses as inspiration while thinking through the Raphael arena/moon staging.
biobak.quote: Let me just see if I can find the video that Biobak had sent me here a while ago… This is what he was thinking. That's so cool.

badub.summary: Kaze praises Badub’s composition quality and creativity while working on importing/playing tracks during the stream.
badub.quote: Badub's music is great. The creativity he brings to the table is very, very sick.

zeina.summary: Zeina briefly participates in the audio discussion (mono vs stereo). Kaze also mentions she has significantly more workload than he does right now, and they banter about parenting tasks.
zeina.quote: Of course, Zeina has a lot more work with it than I do.

findings.summary: ZeroVolt suggests a specific timing/interaction idea around where the orbiting projectiles meet; Kaze reacts positively to the direction while refining what the spawned throwable should be.

A chat suggestion reframes collectible persistence as Banjo-Kazooie-style notes (already collected items remain collected), which Kaze acknowledges as a viable concept in principle while discussing alternatives to Mario 64’s 100-coin-star ejection behavior.
findings.quote: So you mean just Banjo-Kazooie notes? Yes.

key_stories.title: Mapping the Raphael the Raven boss fight around a moon set-piece
key_stories.summary: Kaze uses this stream to get from ‘we need a raven boss’ to a concrete multi-phase fight concept anchored by a moon/tower visual reveal. The story shows how technical constraints (gravity/actor scope) and thematic callbacks (Yoshi’s Island / Galaxy vibes) shape what he’s willing to build.
key_stories.challenge: Design a Raphael the Raven boss fight that feels iconic and ‘Yoshi’s Island’ themed without being a cheap 1:1 remake, and that is feasible within Mario 64’s engine constraints.
key_stories.process: He brainstorms with chat, explores variants (ice Raphael, cheese moon, hollow moon with inside/outside traversal, flipping arena). He rejects hollow-moon universal-gravity changes and instead converges on an actor-friendly approach: low-gravity moon arena + an interlude where Mario is launched into a starfield dodge sequence. He then invents a damage loop: orbiting projectiles meet and create a throwable pickup (eventually ‘frozen cheese’ that becomes ‘unfrozen/sparkling’ to signal interactivity).
key_stories.outcome: By end of stream, Kaze says the boss fight is ‘mapped out’ and identifies next steps: build the moon asset/behavior, implement the intro cutscene, and tackle rotation/planet-gravity via existing code help.
key_stories.key_quote: But I think I'm done for today. We got the boss fight mapped out, which is very good.

key_stories.title: Choosing actor-level solutions over engine-wide gravity changes
key_stories.summary: While exploring the coolest version of the idea (a hollow moon you can traverse inside and outside), Kaze articulates a production rule: avoid global physics rewrites if the feature can be faked at the actor level. This becomes a decision filter for boss concepts going forward.
key_stories.challenge: A true inside/outside moon fight implies custom gravity behavior that could destabilize the project or require widespread engine changes.
key_stories.process: Kaze reasons through how Mario 64 gravity would need to change ‘universally’ for a hollow moon, then reframes the problem: if the fight stays ‘outside only,’ he can rotate actors/geometry to mimic the effect without touching global physics.
key_stories.outcome: He deprioritizes the hollow moon concept and commits to an implementation path that keeps gravity hacks localized/minimized, even if it limits some spectacle options.
key_stories.key_quote: We need to make sure that the things we add can be done entirely on an actor level.

key_stories.title: Ice Dungeon music import and loop-point debugging
key_stories.summary: In parallel to boss work, Kaze demonstrates the practical realities of building a custom OST into a ROM hack: formats, constraints, and hands-on loop editing. It’s a concrete ‘how the sausage is made’ moment that connects composer output to in-game integration.
key_stories.challenge: An Ice Dungeon track needs correct looping and stereo behavior in-game, and Kaze doesn’t have loop points provided.
key_stories.process: He listens for repeatable musical cues, visually aligns waveform/beat patterns, corrects being ‘off by one beat,’ chooses loop in/out times, converts them into engine units (including the ×32 conversion), and tests the result in-game.
key_stories.outcome: The song loops successfully, reinforcing the project’s near-100-track scope and the integration workload involved.
key_stories.key_quote: Time to find the loop points.

open_questions.topic: Arthur’s planetary gravity code and how it changes the boss scope
open_questions.context: Kaze plans to ask Arthur for planetary gravity/rotation code to support the moon concept, but he’s wary of engine-wide changes versus actor-level tricks.
questions: Who is Arthur in the context of RTYI (team member, community contributor), and what past feature did his planetary gravity code support?
When you say ‘actor-level’ solutions, what’s your internal rule for when a feature is allowed to touch global physics?
Did the moon end up using true planetary gravity, a simplified low-gravity field, or a purely visual/rotation trick? What broke during implementation?

open_questions.topic: Final Raphael the Raven fight implementation vs this brainstorm
open_questions.context: The stream produces a full concept: launch-to-stars dodge interludes, moon arena, orbiting projectiles that collide into a throwable damage item, plus nest/egg theming.
questions: What parts of this brainstorm survived unchanged into the playable boss, and what parts had to be cut for technical or pacing reasons?
How did you tune the ‘one to two minutes’ target without making the fight feel trivial?
What did playtesting reveal about camera behavior and readability on a spherical/rotating arena?

open_questions.topic: Egg choice as narrative signal (Yoshi egg vs raven egg)
open_questions.context: Kaze likes the idea that the nest egg ‘becomes’ the reward star and debates whether the egg should be a captured Yoshi egg to motivate the villainy.
questions: What story beat did you want the egg to communicate—Raphael protecting something, stealing from Yoshis, or a twist reveal?
Did you end up tying that egg to any broader plot/collectible throughline in RTYI, or is it purely a boss-room payoff?
How did you design the visual effect of the egg ‘exploding into a star’ within N64 constraints?

open_questions.topic: Fast64 fog/material bleeding bug and shipping on real hardware
open_questions.context: Kaze attributes Course 12’s N64 visuals looking worse than stream footage to a Fast64 issue where fog state isn’t properly disabled within a large display list when material bleeding is used.
questions: How often do Fast64 export bugs force you to redesign materials/level art, versus fixing them with post-export tooling or manual display-list edits?
Did this fog-state issue lead to any pipeline changes (e.g., avoiding certain material setups, splitting display lists, different authoring rules)?
How do you validate that what viewers see on emulator/stream will match real N64 output before release?

open_questions.context: Kaze says he intentionally avoided looking at the Nintendo gigaleak because merely knowing about it could ‘get you in trouble.’
questions: Was that a legal fear (copyright/trade secrets) or a community/ethical line you didn’t want to cross—or both?
Did avoiding the gigaleak ever cost you time (rebuilding something that leaked docs could have clarified), and was that tradeoff worth it?
Did you set any explicit rules for collaborators about what references/tools are allowed?
